--- title: "Class 10: Scientific Publishing and the Replication Crisis" bibliography: ../references.bib --- ## Slides The slides are available online as an HTML file. You can also download them in a static PDF (for printing or storing for later). You can also click in the slides below and navigate through them with your left and right arrow keys.

View all slides in new window Download PDF of all slides

## Readings I don't expect you to read all these, but in case you're curious, here are some papers mentioned in class: - @opensciencecollaborationEstimatingReproducibilityPsychological2015 - @simmonsFalsePositivePsychologyUndisclosed2011 - @gouldSameDataDifferent2025 - @turnerSelectivePublicationAntidepressant2008 For a refresher on hypothesis testing and statistical power, you could can have a look at the begging of [chapter 2](https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/02-errorcontrol.html) in @lakensImprovingYourStatistical2022d Since the lecture did not really cover this, if you want to know what's wrong with scientific publishing, [this old (but gold!) article of the Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/jun/27/profitable-business-scientific-publishing-bad-for-science) is a good read. It's also available as a podcast. ## Data - [{{< fa table >}} `imaginary_beatle_experiment.csv`](../data/imaginary_beatle_experiment.csv) ## Assignment No assignment for this session ðŸŽ‰
